title: I Work Full-Time – How Do I Fit Soroban Into Our Schedule?
description: Getting home at 7pm exhausted, the last thing I wanted was another commitment. Here's how we made Soroban work with our crazy schedule.
imageAlt: Working parent supporting child's Soroban practice at home

content.intro: I get home at 7pm most nights. By then, I'm running on empty. Homework battles? No thanks. So when I heard Soroban required "daily practice," I almost didn't even try. Here's how we actually made it work.

sections.text: The Problem: Time We Don't Have
Between work, dinner, and basic survival, there's no slot labeled "enrichment activities" in our evening. Weekends are for catching up on sleep and errands.
Traditional Soroban classes? Forget it. Fixed times, driving across town, waiting during class – impossible.
We do Soroban right after dinner, before screen time. It's non-negotiable: 15 minutes, then she can watch her show.
That's it. No driving. No waiting. Just 15 minutes on the tablet while I clean up dishes nearby.
The secret isn't finding more time – it's fitting into time that already exists. We attached Soroban to an existing routine (after dinner) so it became automatic.

items: **No commute:** Practice happens in our kitchen
**Self-paced:** She goes at her speed, not a class's pace
**Progress tracking:** I can check her stats without sitting there the whole time

sections.text: I worried online learning would be inferior. But after 6 months, her mental math is noticeably better. Her school math confidence improved too.
The app teaches better than I could anyway. It's patient, consistent, and doesn't get tired after a long work day.
If you're a busy parent feeling guilty about not having time for enrichment activities – 15 minutes is enough. Consistency matters more than duration.

faq.question: Is 15 minutes really enough?
faq.answer: For building skills, yes. Research shows short, daily practice beats longer occasional sessions. 15 focused minutes daily adds up to 7.5 hours monthly.

faq.question: What if I can't be present during practice?
faq.answer: The app works independently. Many parents have kids practice while they're cooking or doing chores nearby. You don't need to actively supervise every minute.

faq.question: Don't kids need in-person instruction?
faq.answer: For Soroban fundamentals, apps teach very effectively. In-person can add value for advanced levels or competition prep, but isn't necessary for most kids.

cta.text: Busy schedule? Sorokid fits into 15 minutes – practice anywhere, anytime.
